For the second day in a row, there have been no buyers literally no bids for Japan‚Äôs 30-year and 40-year government bonds. Yields on both have exploded higher, with the 40-year jumping past 3.63%, and the 30-year hitting 3.16%. These are massive, sudden moves that point to one thing: something is breaking beneath the surface.

The Bank of Japan has spent years trying to suppress volatility in its bond market using a policy known as yield curve control essentially capping interest rates on shorter-term bonds. But that approach has created severe distortions. It worked for a while, but now the longer-term part of the bond market where investors are most sensitive to risk and inflation is breaking away from that control. And for now, the BOJ appears to be sitting on its hands.

Why does this matter beyond Japan?

Because Japan‚Äôs bond market is the second-largest in the world. These bonds are used in global funding strategies and as collateral in other financial systems. When they lose stability, it affects more than just Japan. It spills over into the broader financial system into foreign exchange markets, swap lines, and global liquidity.

This also raises serious questions about what could happen to the U.S. Treasury market. If a country like Japan with tight domestic ownership of its debt and decades of financial repression can lose control of its long-term bonds, what does that mean for the U.S., which is running record deficits, facing declining foreign demand, and relying more on domestic investors to absorb its growing debt?

To be clear this isn‚Äôt just about volatility. It‚Äôs about a lack of liquidity and a loss of credibility. Japan‚Äôs bond market has long been considered a place where monetary policy could bend the rules. But now we may be witnessing what happens when those rules can‚Äôt hold anymore.

This is Japan‚Äôs version of the U.K.‚Äôs ‚Äúgilt crisis‚Äù in 2022 but on a much larger and more systemically important scale. And if this continues, it could quickly become a global story.

What‚Äôs Really Driving the 10-Year Yield Higher?

The 10-year Treasury yield just climbed to 4.542% and it‚Äôs not because the economy is overheating.

Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs actually happening under the hood:

This move in the 10Y is a stress signal not a growth signal. While CPI is cooling and GDP just contracted in Q1 (-0.3%), the long end is still rising. Why? Because we‚Äôre watching the bond market try to absorb a flood of issuance without its historical buyers.

Foreign official demand is weak. Domestic balance sheet capacity is saturated. And with the Fed still engaged in QT (Quantitative Tightening), there‚Äôs no lender-of-last-resort stepping in to cap the curve.

At the same time, SOMA reinvestments are quietly being used like stealth QE recycling principal and interest back into shorter maturities but they can‚Äôt match the scale or tenor of new 10Y auctions. That leaves the private market to eat the full duration risk.

So what does this mean? The rising 10Y yield is a pricing mechanism for duration indigestion. It‚Äôs not about growth or inflation it‚Äôs about absorption risk. If this continues, we‚Äôll likely see it bleed into:
‚Ä¢Wider mortgage spreads (housing stress),
‚Ä¢Lower bond market liquidity (bid-ask gaps widen),
‚Ä¢Pressure on long-duration tech and utility stocks.

Unless the Fed intervenes openly or covertly this is how financial plumbing reveals its cracks: not in headlines, but in basis points.

Scott Bessent is executing a deliberate, forward leaning restructuring of U.S. Treasury issuance that blends financial repression, soft yield curve control, and liquidity engineering, all without overtly stepping on the Federal Reserve‚Äôs turf. At first glance, it may look like a shift toward short term debt for funding convenience. But beneath the surface, it‚Äôs a tactical move to reassert control over the long end of the curve and ease systemic funding pressure without triggering market panic.

The strategy is two pronged: first, Bessent is leaning heavily into Treasury bills, those maturing in less than one year because they carry lower interest costs and roll over quickly. This allows the government to finance massive deficits while avoiding locking in high long term rates. This is a bet that either future rates will fall or that inflation will quietly erode the real burden of the debt.

Second, Bessent is now doubling down on Treasury buybacks, particularly of long dated bonds issued at much higher yields. These buybacks reduce the average interest cost of the debt and smooth market functioning but they also suppress long end yields in a way that mimics quantitative easing, without requiring Fed balance sheet expansion. Buybacks are now running at over $300 billion per year, with long end operations expanding and new counterparties being phased in for 2026. This is targeted curve management.

All of this suggests a silent alignment with Jerome Powell‚Äôs Federal Reserve. The two reportedly meet weekly, and Powell has publicly hinted that the Treasury can support bond market functioning. With the Fed refusing to cut rates quickly, Bessent‚Äôs moves act as a liquidity offset, preserving short end demand, dampening long end volatility, and buying time for fiscal breathing room. This is de facto fiscal monetary coordination, even if it‚Äôs not formally acknowledged.

The risk is the U.S. is increasingly exposed to rollover fragility. By front loading debt into the bill market, the Treasury is making itself vulnerable to any disruption in short-duration demand, whether from money markets, foreign buyers, or liquidity shocks. If confidence in short term instruments wavers, the whole structure could wobble.

In essence, Bessent is rearchitecting the Treasury‚Äôs role as a macroeconomic actor. This is about controlling the curve, anchoring expectations, and projecting calm in a system that‚Äôs far more brittle than the headlines suggest.

Ishiba isn‚Äôt resigning because of bad poll numbers or party drama. He is resigning because he became the fall guy in a much bigger game, one where Japan‚Äôs entire economic strategy hit a wall, and the United States finally called its bluff. For years, Japan survived on a mix of financial repression, currency suppression, and quiet support from the U.S.-led global order. But that structure is breaking. The U.S. is no longer willing to let allies export deflation, run cheap currencies, or manipulate bond markets while America absorbs the inflation and finances global security. Ishiba found himself caught in the crosshairs of that shift.

When Scott Bessent, the U.S. Treasury Secretary visited Japan earlier this month, it wasn‚Äôt just to attend a ceremonial event. He came to deliver a message. Behind closed doors, he likely told Japan‚Äôs leadership to stop weakening the yen, scale back the BOJ‚Äôs yield curve control, and agree to a new trade framework or face 25% auto tariffs, possible capital flight, and reduced access to dollar support mechanisms. That wasn‚Äôt a warning. It was a line in the sand.

Ishiba was already under pressure. Japan‚Äôs economy contracted in Q1, real wages are still falling, and his party took a beating in the upper house elections just days before. When Trump announced the U.S.‚ÄìJapan trade deal on yesterday, including a 15% tariff instead of 25%, and a $550 billion Japanese investment pledge into the U.S., it was billed as a win. But everyone inside Tokyo knew that it meant Japan had conceded. The U.S. didn‚Äôt just get a better trade deal, it forced Japan to fall in line with its broader economic and strategic agenda.

So why would Ishiba resign after striking that deal? Because in the eyes of his own political class, he gave up too much. The deal might have prevented harsher tariffs, but it exposed how weak Japan‚Äôs position had become. Ishiba looked like a leader who couldn‚Äôt protect Japan‚Äôs autonomy or economy. And once the agreement was signed, there was no more political reason to keep him in place. His job was done. He‚Äôd absorbed the blame and cleared the path for someone else to carry out the post deal restructuring.

At the core of all this is something deeper: Japan‚Äôs old playbook no longer works. The three things that held the country together, cheap borrowing via BOJ control, demographic stability to absorb shocks, and quiet U.S. support, have all failed. The bond market‚Äôs starting to push back, inflation is squeezing households, and Washington is no longer willing to tolerate Japan‚Äôs monetary games. In that environment, Ishiba didn‚Äôt have room to lead. He had no tools left. He didn‚Äôt step down just because he lost support. He stepped down because the entire system he was trying to manage stopped working.

Now Japan enters a new era. It‚Äôs no longer the quietly independent industrial power navigating a middle path between great powers. It‚Äôs becoming a tightly bound ally in a U.S. centric order, on trade, on monetary policy, on defense. The resignation wasn‚Äôt just about Ishiba. It was about a shift in the global structure. His fall was the signal that Japan‚Äôs strategic ambiguity is over and the era of quiet balancing has been replaced by open alignment.

This is about rerouting a tidal wave of captive capital, trillions locked in 401(k)s into private markets that are increasingly illiquid, overvalued, and in desperate need of fresh inflows. Behind the populist framing lies a deeper truth: public markets are saturated, institutional alpha is drying up, and private equity firms are sitting on aging portfolios they can‚Äôt exit without fresh retail money to take the baton.

Opening 401(k)s to private investments under an executive order circumvents much of the traditional legislative oversight that would normally accompany such a structural shift. It compresses a massive change in fiduciary standards into a top down mandate, effectively using policy as a liquidity injection into elite capital channels. And it raises a subtle but critical question: what happens when the retirement system is turned into a shadow bailout engine for the private capital complex?

For the average saver, the promise is access to higher returns. But what they‚Äôre less likely to understand is that private markets come with steep fees, limited transparency, longer lock ups, and mark to model valuations that can obscure downside risk until it‚Äôs too late. The democratization narrative masks a more urgent reality: institutional capital is saturated, IPO windows are narrow, and pension fund math no longer works without higher yielding alternatives. Retail capital, locked up for decades, becomes the ideal backstop.

This is not about giving you access, it‚Äôs about giving them an exit. And if the cycle turns before those assets mature, it‚Äôs everyday Americans who will absorb the losses long after the headlines have faded. The executive order may well be framed as visionary but beneath the surface, it‚Äôs a silent reordering of who carries the bag when the private market tide goes out.

tweets.text:
Lesson on Currencies: Why the Dollar Rises (Even When You Think It Shouldn‚Äôt)

If you‚Äôre new to currencies or macroeconomics, here‚Äôs one of the biggest mindset shifts to understand: currencies don‚Äôt move based solely on what‚Äôs happening inside one country. They move based on how that country looks compared to everyone else. That ‚Äúrelative strength‚Äù concept is the foundation for understanding why the U.S. dollar often behaves in ways that seem counterintuitive.

A lot of people assume that when the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates, the dollar must fall. And in a vacuum, that makes sense, lower rates reduce returns for dollar denominated assets, making the currency less attractive. But we don‚Äôt live in a vacuum. If the Fed is cutting, it‚Äôs likely in response to something bigger, slowing growth, global instability, or synchronized weakness. And if the rest of the world is facing even deeper problems, like deflation in China, stagflation in Europe, or a sovereign debt scare in emerging markets,then investors don‚Äôt run away from the dollar. They run toward it.

This is what Brent Johnson‚Äôs (@SantiagoAuFund) ‚ÄúDollar Milkshake Theory‚Äù captures so well. Over the past decade plus, the U.S. flooded the world with dollars through trade, lending, and monetary policy. Global economies became deeply intertwined with the dollar system. But when the U.S. tightens policy or even just looks more resilient than the alternatives, global investors scramble to pull those dollars back home, like sucking up a milkshake through a straw. The result is a paradox: the very system that made the dollar abundant now makes it scarce during stress, because so much global debt and trade still relies on it.

Now imagine the Fed cuts rates. That should weaken the dollar, right? But let‚Äôs say they‚Äôre cutting because China‚Äôs economy is imploding, Europe‚Äôs energy crisis is flaring back up, and credit markets are showing cracks. Suddenly, a 4% Treasury yield starts to look like a gift from the heavens compared to collapsing foreign assets. Investors don‚Äôt just look at the absolute rate, they look at safety, liquidity, and trust. And the U.S., for all its flaws, still has the deepest, most liquid markets on Earth.

What that means is that the dollar can rise even in easing cycles. If the rest of the world is more unstable or if global liquidity is deteriorating, demand for dollars increases because investors need them to cover dollar denominated debt, park capital in safe havens, or hedge against risk. That‚Äôs why crises often come with a dollar spike, not a collapse. The dollar becomes the eye of the storm.

People also underestimate how much of the world‚Äôs financial plumbing is priced in dollars. When cracks appear, global borrowers scramble to secure funding, and the strongest pressure always falls on the weakest currencies. You don‚Äôt get a clean handoff from dollar to yuan or euro; you get a lurching flight to safety, then a reset.

So when you hear someone confidently say the dollar must fall because the Fed is loosening policy, take a step back. Currencies aren‚Äôt just about monetary policy, they‚Äôre about trust, leverage, and global imbalances. A weaker dollar only emerges when the rest of the world is strong enough to support it. Until then, the dollar remains the currency of last resort, often rising not in spite of global stress, but because of it.

That‚Äôs the lesson. Currencies are a mirror of global comparison, not just domestic direction. And in a world built on dollar obligations, pressure doesn‚Äôt break the dollar, it reinforces its dominance.

What‚Äôs unfolding right now is a layered geopolitical maneuver that goes far beyond a tariff dispute. By doubling tariffs on Indian goods to 50%, the U.S. is weaponizing market access to pressure India over its continued purchases of Russian oil. This is, in effect, a form of secondary sanctions enforcement without officially labeling it as such. The goal is to force compliance with Western efforts to economically isolate Moscow, but the risk is that such a hardline approach may push India into deeper alignment with non Western blocs.

That risk now looks even sharper given the new development that Prime Minister Modi is set to visit China on August 31 for the first time in six years. The timing is crucial. A high profile trip to Beijing just weeks after Washington escalates tariffs sends a clear signal that India is willing to explore closer cooperation with China, its fellow BRICS member and a major buyer of discounted Russian crude. While India and China have had border tensions and competing strategic aims, shared interests in energy security, alternative payment systems, and resisting U.S. trade pressure could drive pragmatic engagement.

This is where the U.S. move may backfire. Instead of isolating India, the tariffs could accelerate the very multipolar realignment Washington seeks to slow. A Beijing/New Delhi thaw, especially one underpinned by energy and trade agreements would strengthen BRICS economic leverage, expand non-dollar settlement networks, and weaken the impact of Western sanctions. It would also create a new reality for American businesses that have been shifting supply chains from China to India: they could find themselves exposed to the same geopolitical risks they were trying to avoid.

In short, the U.S. tariffs are meant to force India to choose but Modi‚Äôs upcoming visit to China suggests New Delhi may instead choose to play both sides, extracting concessions from each. That could reshape not only U.S.‚ÄìIndia relations, but the architecture of global trade and energy flows for the next decade.

(1) THE BESSENT DOCTRINE
This Wasn‚Äôt a Bailout. It Was a Blueprint for Monetary Realignment.

April 23, 2025, may end up being remembered not for what Bessent rescued, but for what he reframed. At a time when swap spreads were collapsing, gold had surged to record highs, volatility was spiking across FX and credit, and Treasury auctions were increasingly relying on domestic buyers, markets were primed for a policy backstop.

Instead, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent delivered something very different.

What We Expected: A Liquidity Lifeline

My original framing ‚ÄúThe Bessent Signal: Why This Isn‚Äôt Just a Routine Update‚Äù was built around historical precedent. When Treasury officials suddenly announce speeches on ‚Äúthe financial system,‚Äù it often signals imminent action. Think:
‚Ä¢Paulson pre-TARP (2008)
‚Ä¢Yellen pre-BTFP (March 2023)

Combine that with collapsing SOFR-OIS spreads, FX volatility (USD/ILS, USD/EUR pairs), and shifts in T-bill auction demand toward domestic fallback buyers (Berkshire, MMFs), the stage looked set for a stealth liquidity intervention.

I warned followers to watch for keywords like ‚Äúmarket plumbing,‚Äù ‚Äúliquidity alignment,‚Äù or ‚Äúresilience at the short end‚Äù code for balance sheet expansion without calling it QE.

What We Got: The Bessent Doctrine

But instead of rescue language, we got re-architecture:

1.China Is Now the Target
Bessent directly attacked China‚Äôs economic model calling out opaque FX practices, IMF leniency, and World Bank classification games. He framed China as gaming the system and insisted it must ‚Äúgraduate‚Äù into fair competition. This wasn‚Äôt diplomatic it was declarative.

2.The U.S. Shadow System Is Admitted, Not Hidden
Bessent said the quiet part out loud: private credit is now a core engine of U.S. economic growth but it operates outside the traditional regulatory perimeter. He signaled that post-2008 financial regulation has constrained traditional intermediation to the point where markets built a shadow alternative.
Translation: the Fed regulates one system; the economy runs on another.

3.Not a Bailout. A Geoeconomic Blueprint.
This wasn‚Äôt a ‚Äúmarkets are breaking‚Äù speech. This was a ‚Äúwe‚Äôre reshaping the monetary order‚Äù moment. Bessent positioned the U.S. as the enforcer of new trade terms, using Treasury power, not Fed balance sheet. If China wants capital access, it must rebalance toward internal demand. If Europe wants U.S. support, it must raise fiscal spending (as Germany is now doing). And if allies want liquidity, they must align with U.S. values.

https://t.co/wJ2WKVZxvO Explicit Liquidity Action Yet
The expected intervention terms never came. No mention of expanding repo lines, adjusting standing facilities, or new funding support tools. That tells us one thing: the stress is real, but the panic threshold hasn‚Äôt been crossed.
Bessent‚Äôs job was to control the narrative before the flows fracture.

What we‚Äôre witnessing tonight isn‚Äôt the birth of a bull market it‚Äôs a mirage formed by narrative whiplash and liquidity exhaustion. The spike in futures following Trump‚Äôs comments is less about policy and more about psychological relief. Markets are starved for any catalyst that offers a pathway out of the tightening vise of global funding stress, swap spread inversions, and deflationary positioning. But this is not structural it‚Äôs reactive.

When you peel back the surface, the macro plumbing tells a very different story. SOFR stress is still rising. 3-year swap spreads are negative. USD/JPY continues to act like a carry-trade coiled spring. And credit markets where real money expresses macro conviction have not confirmed any kind of sustainable risk-on regime. You don‚Äôt get a healthy rally when the cost of capital is still breaking things in the background. You get a ‚Äúplug-the-hole‚Äù bid temporary, unstable, and often violently reversed.

This futures surge feels like a classic gamma reversion pop. Dealers were offsides, vol was overstretched, and short-dated flow had built up in the wrong direction. Add in AI sentiment sensitivity and politically driven headline algorithms, and the result is mechanical upside not organic bullish conviction. tweets.text:
Echoes of 1929? The Great Depression vs. Today‚Äôs Fragile System

The Great Depression wasn‚Äôt the result of a single cataclysm it was the cumulative failure of interconnected systems: excessive leverage, speculative bubbles, policy missteps, and rising global protectionism. The 1929 stock market crash was merely the ignition point. What followed was a devastating cascade: the Federal Reserve contracted liquidity instead of expanding it; the U.S. Congress passed the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act in 1930, sparking a global trade war; and waves of banking panics decimated credit availability. U.S. GDP collapsed by 26%, unemployment surged past 25%, and the global economy fell into a multi-year malaise.

Fast-forward to 2025, and we find ourselves staring into a similarly unstable landscape but one with far more complexity, opacity, and institutionalized moral hazard. While monetary tools are more sophisticated and global institutions more coordinated, the systemic risk is broader, the leverage deeper, and the ability to course-correct arguably weaker.

tweets.text:
üáØüáµ Japan Just Lost Its Status as the World‚Äôs Largest Creditor | Here‚Äôs Why That Matters More Than You Think

‚∏ª

For the first time in over 30 years, Japan is no longer the world‚Äôs top net international creditor. That title now belongs to Germany. At first glance, this might seem like a minor reshuffling of global balance sheets. It‚Äôs not. It‚Äôs a tectonic shift beneath the surface of the global financial system a signal that the world‚Äôs capital flows, debt structures, and geopolitical leverage points are realigning in ways that could have massive second-order consequences.

What Just Happened?

Japan‚Äôs net international investment position (NIIP) fell by a record ¬•20.8 trillion (US$133 billion) last year, bringing it below Germany‚Äôs. For context, the NIIP is the difference between what a country owns abroad and what it owes the rest of the world. Japan had been at the top of that creditor list since 1991, recycling its trade surpluses and savings into the global financial system particularly U.S. Treasuries.

Now that position is slipping. And that slip isn‚Äôt just about numbers it‚Äôs about behavior, risk, and capital strategy.

‚∏ª

Why Is This Happening?

1.The Yield Trap Is Breaking:
Japan‚Äôs bond yields are rising. The 10-year JGB is near 1%, and the 30-year recently surged past 2.75% a multi-decade high. Higher yields at home mean Japanese institutions no longer need to chase returns abroad. And when they do invest overseas, a weaker yen punishes them.
https://t.co/sZSJwdmTzd Repatriation Is Underway:
Japanese insurers, pensions, and megabanks are reducing foreign exposure, especially U.S. Treasuries, due to rising global volatility and currency losses. That means fewer buyers for U.S. debt and more strain on American deficit financing.
3.BOJ Is Cornered:
The Bank of Japan is caught in a trilemma: it can‚Äôt simultaneously cap yields, defend the yen, and sustain foreign capital exports. With the yen under pressure (briefly touching 160 per dollar), Japan is being forced to prioritize domestic solvency.

‚∏ª

Why It Matters Globally

‚Ä¢The U.S. Treasury Market Just Lost a Major Buyer: Japan has long been one of the largest foreign holders of U.S. Treasuries. If Japanese institutions are now net sellers or even passive non-buyer who fills the gap? The answer will likely require higher yields or covert intervention by the Fed.
‚Ä¢Global Liquidity Is Tightening Indirectly: Fewer Japanese capital exports means less global liquidity. That tightens conditions in Europe, emerging markets, and even the U.S., where capital needs to be coaxed with better risk-adjusted returns.
‚Ä¢Germany‚Äôs Rise Is Not a Sign of Strength: Germany overtaking Japan isn‚Äôt about growth it‚Äôs about suppressed domestic demand and a growing surplus that has nowhere to go. It signals European stagnation, not expansion.

‚∏ª

Zooming Out: Structural Implications

This isn‚Äôt just a Japan story. It‚Äôs a marker of regime transition in the post-1980s global financial order. Japan‚Äôs decades-long role as a capital exporter, surplus recycler, and passive stabilizer of the U.S.-led financial system is fading.

We‚Äôre now watching in real-time as:
‚Ä¢Surplus nations start repatriating capital to stabilize their own currencies and aging populations.
‚Ä¢Foreign demand for U.S. debt erodes at the exact moment the U.S. is issuing record levels of it.
‚Ä¢FX volatility becomes a geopolitical weapon, not just a market side effect.

Final Thought:

‚Ä¢10-Year SOFR Swap Spread: ‚àí55 bps

‚∏ª

What Are Swap Spreads Telling Us?

In normal times, SOFR swaps should yield more than equivalent-maturity Treasuries because swaps carry counterparty risk. When the swap spread goes negative, it means markets are treating Treasuries as riskier than swaps a complete reversal of what ‚Äúrisk-free‚Äù is supposed to mean.

This usually happens when:
‚Ä¢Dealer balance sheets are maxed out
‚Ä¢There‚Äôs a shortage of clean collateral
‚Ä¢Funding markets are tightening
‚Ä¢Liquidity is being hoarded, not recycled

We‚Äôve been here before:
‚Ä¢Q4 2018: Fed overtightens
‚Ä¢Sept 2019: Repo market cracks
‚Ä¢March 2020: Pandemic panic
‚Ä¢March 2023: SVB & regional bank crisis

And now‚Ä¶ May 2025. Another inflection point.

‚∏ª

This Is a Policy Signal Not a Market Fluke

Don‚Äôt be fooled by narratives blaming supply, auctions, or ‚Äúdealer positioning.‚Äù When swap spreads stay this negative across both the 10Y and 30Y curve, the problem is structural. This is the market saying ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt trust the clearing function. We don‚Äôt trust the liquidity. And we‚Äôre starting to question the collateral.‚Äù

‚Ä¢Maintaining the illusion of control (QT, strong dollar, policy independence)

‚Ä¢Verbal jawboning

Ignore the inflation narratives for a moment. This isn‚Äôt about consumer prices. It‚Äôs about systemic confidence in U.S. Treasury functioning, dealer balance sheet capacity, and the invisible cost of hoarding collateral in a fractured global credit regime.

What you‚Äôre seeing isn‚Äôt random. It‚Äôs a plumbing-level stress test. The kind that front-runs headlines. The kind that breaks things before they appear in economic data. And the kind that historically ends with the Fed forced to intervene quietly or otherwise.

When drilling activity declines to this extent, it‚Äôs not just a near-term production cut it‚Äôs a structural throttling of future supply capacity. Shuttering oil wells, especially unconventional ones like shale, isn‚Äôt as simple as flipping a switch. Once a rig is idled, crews are disbanded, capital is reallocated, and permits may lapse. Restarting production requires not only fresh CapEx and labor, but the reassembly of a complex ecosystem of service providers, equipment logistics, and regulatory alignment often taking 6 to 18 months depending on jurisdiction and depth.

This lag effect creates a powerful asymmetry: supply destruction happens fast, but supply restoration is slow and uncertain. If global demand rebounds before the supply side has had time to recalibrate, we risk a sharp price spike not just due to fundamentals, but due to market participants front-running the inevitable scarcity. It‚Äôs a classic boom bust setup forming quietly in real time. The longer this underinvestment persists, the more violently prices could respond when the cycle turns.

In a world obsessed with near term disinflation, this is the kind of deferred energy risk that becomes headline inflation shock when it finally catches up. Few are pricing in that dynamic now.

‚Ä¢Tether‚Äôs claim of owning over 100,000 Bitcoin and more than 50 tons of gold raises more questions than it answers, especially with no third-party audits.

King‚Äôs claim is straightforward: Tether and Bitcoin are locked in a mutually reinforcing cycle. Tether supports Bitcoin by buying it with freshly minted USDT. Bitcoin‚Äôs rising price, in turn, lends legitimacy to Tether‚Äôs reserves. Throughout modern financial history, Japan has consistently acted as an early warning system for deeper structural stress in the global monetary order. When you overlay today‚Äôs actions with BOJ supplying USD against pooled collateral, rising JGB yields, and cabinet level political overtures on inflation with past episodes like 1997‚Äì98, 2008, and 2020, a disturbing pattern emerges. Each time Japan steps in to provide dollar liquidity and domestic policymakers begin signaling coordinated political action around prices, the global system is already under unseen strain. And more importantly, these signals rarely remain contained. On average, a 3‚Äì6 month lag has occurred between these interventions and a broader systemic event: in 1997 it preceded the Russian default and LTCM collapse; in 2008, Japanese liquidity operations emerged ahead of the Lehman moment; in March 2020, the signs flashed weeks before dollar scarcity forced coordinated central bank action and risk assets cratered.

What makes the current moment more critical is the underlying context we‚Äôve discussed, Japan is no longer just a deflationary bellwether or passive participant. It is now structurally embedded in the global dollar plumbing as both a supplier of capital (through its institutional bond holdings) and a massive importer of commodities priced in USD. With the 10Y JGB creeping toward 1.54%, Japan is facing yield curve instability, rising hedging costs, and capital outflow risk, just as it‚Äôs being asked to stabilize dollar liquidity for others. That‚Äôs a dangerous feedback loop. Meanwhile, the BOJ‚Äôs decision to accept pooled collateral for USD lending points to a shortage of pristine dollar collateral, echoing the collateral crunch seen before prior crises. It‚Äôs a sign of stress beneath the surface of repo markets and a weakening confidence in global funding transmission.

The political dimension matters too. The Japanese cabinet openly discussing cross party efforts on price measures shows that domestic inflation pressures are no longer deniable, even in a culture that resists overt confrontation. This mirrors the lead up to the 1998 stimulus and 2020 fiscal bursts, both of which preceded global liquidity fractures.

So what‚Äôs happening now is not isolated, it‚Äôs a historically recognizable pattern. Japan is once again the shock absorber, bearing the burden of dollar scarcity, sovereign yield stress, political inflation pressure, and system wide funding dysfunction. And if precedent holds, this moment doesn‚Äôt resolve quietly. It builds pressure globally until something breaks, just not in Japan first, but through the weakest external node tethered to the same fragile plumbing. That‚Äôs the clock we‚Äôre on now.

This might look like just another central bank liquidity move, but it‚Äôs not. The BOJ stepping in to supply U.S. dollars against pooled collateral starting July 17 is one of those quiet, technical shifts that says more than any press release ever could. To me, this is about what‚Äôs coming for the entire global dollar system.

What I think is going on is Japanese institutions are feeling the squeeze. They‚Äôve been running massive USD carry trades, borrowing in yen, buying U.S. assets, hedging the FX. That worked when dollar liquidity was easy and the hedge was cheap. But with Powell holding rates high and the yen tanking, the math‚Äôs breaking down. Rolling over those trades is getting riskier and more expensive. The BOJ‚Äôs stepping in not to fix a crisis, but to prevent one. They‚Äôre trying to calm their own system, keep Japanese firms from having to dump Treasuries or scramble for dollars in the open market. It‚Äôs preemptive firefighting.

But this isn‚Äôt just about Japan. This is about global dollar scarcity bleeding through the system. When one major central bank starts injecting USD liquidity domestically, it means private markets aren‚Äôt doing the job anymore. The cross currency basis has likely been widening under the surface. The U.S. is exporting interest rate pain, and the rest of the world is being forced to react. This kind of move hints that global demand for dollars is rising, and supply is getting tight. It‚Äôs not dramatic yet but it‚Äôs how stress starts.

And we‚Äôve seen this movie before. 2008. 2011. 2019. 2020. Whenever global markets start losing confidence in clean, affordable access to dollar funding, things start to break. What follows? Fed swap lines get tapped. Repo markets seize. U.S. yields behave erratically. Foreign holders start unloading U.S. assets. And before you know it, the Fed has to step in, not because inflation is fixed, but because the global system is wobbling. This BOJ move feels like the opening credits to that kind of film.

So why now? Because they see what‚Äôs coming. Q3 and Q4 are stacked with dollar denominated debt maturities, especially in Asia and emerging markets. If those borrowers can‚Äôt roll their debt easily or if hedging costs keep climbing then we‚Äôre in for a wave of defensive firewalls going up. The BOJ is just the first to move. They‚Äôre telling you that dollar liquidity is tightening, and nobody wants to be caught flat footed when it cracks.

Central banks don‚Äôt do this stuff unless they‚Äôre feeling pressure behind the scenes. If this becomes a trend and if others follow then Powell‚Äôs hawkish delay game may be hitting the outer edge of what the global system can take before he‚Äôs forced to intervene. Quiet moves like this one are often the first signs.

tweets.text:
When Japan‚Äôs 30-year bond yield rises sharply, it typically sets off a powerful chain reaction through global markets, and the U.S. dollar often strengthens as a result. This dynamic is rooted in Japan‚Äôs central role in global carry trades. Investors have long borrowed in low-yielding yen and funneled that capital into higher-yielding U.S. assets. But when JGB yields climb, especially at the long end, it raises the cost of that funding and begins to unwind the trade. Capital flees from risk assets into the most liquid, yield secure instruments, and the dollar benefits as a result. This pattern has played out repeatedly: during the 1994 bond selloff, the 2013 taper tantrum, and most visibly in 2022 when the BOJ‚Äôs yield curve control cracked under pressure, triggering a surge in both Japanese and U.S. long yields and a strengthening greenback.

Some historical episodes saw rising JGB yields coincide with a weaker dollar, but those periods were defined by extraordinary and coordinated global easing. In 2016, the BOJ‚Äôs launch of YCC intersected with a genuine Fed pause, creating a narrow window where rate differentials narrowed and the dollar softened. Again in late 2020 to early 2021, central banks were united in stimulus, fiscal and monetary liquidity was abundant, and global markets had synchronized into a reflation regime. That environment suppressed volatility and weakened the dollar even as Japanese rates crept higher. Today‚Äôs backdrop couldn‚Äôt be more different. While Powell hasn‚Äôt hiked recently, he‚Äôs maintaining the highest real policy rate among developed economies. With Europe, Canada, and Australia cutting or signaling cuts and China in structural easing mode, the Fed stands apart, reinforcing the dollar‚Äôs yield magnetism.

This divergence matters. Japan‚Äôs long end volatility is a signal of deepening stress in global bond plumbing. If Japan‚Äôs central bank continues to lose control of its yield curve while the Fed stays firm, capital flow dynamics shift decisively back into U.S. dollar assets. Unless we see an abrupt return to coordinated global easing or a wholesale collapse in U.S. inflation expectations, history points to the dollar firming, not fading in response to this kind of dislocation. And for BRICS and others betting on a weakening U.S. financial center, the timing couldn‚Äôt be worse. What we‚Äôre watching may be less a turning point than a reinforcement of the very system they‚Äôve been trying to exit.

üáØüáµ Japan‚Äôs Long End Reckoning and the Global Shockwave

The surge in Japan‚Äôs 30 year government bond yield to all time highs is the unwinding of one of the most important anchors in the global financial system. For decades, Japan‚Äôs long end sat at the heart of global stability, pinned down by chronic deflation, aging demographics, and the Bank of Japan‚Äôs aggressive yield curve control. That regime has fractured, and the consequences reach far beyond Tokyo.

At home, the drivers are structural. Japan is carrying debt north of 250% of GDP while still running record fiscal deficits. With the BOJ stepping back from being the buyer of last resort, private markets are being forced to reprice sovereign risk. Inflation, once assumed impossible in Japan has returned, fueled by wage growth, imported costs from a persistently weak yen, and a global environment where disinflation no longer comes free. Investors now demand a premium to hold long duration JGBs, and yields are responding with historic speed.

But the real story is the global transmission. For years, Japanese institutional investors recycled domestic savings into U.S. Treasuries, European sovereigns, and global credit, often hedging their FX exposure at heavy cost. With JGBs finally offering more than 3% at the long end, the calculus changes. The after hedge return on U.S. Treasuries looks less attractive, leading to repatriation of capital or at least a sharp slowdown in foreign buying. This acts as a stealth tightening on the U.S., lifting the term premium even as the Fed signals rate cuts. Mortgage rates, corporate borrowing costs, and long end Treasury yields stay sticky higher, an imported tightening cycle courtesy of Tokyo.

Europe is not spared either. With Bunds and Gilts already navigating inflation and tariff driven pressures, higher Japanese yields risk drawing capital back toward JGBs, putting upward pressure on European long rates and widening periphery spreads. For countries like Italy, where fiscal fragility mirrors Japan‚Äôs but without its domestic savings buffer, the risk of spillover stress is real. Meanwhile, in Asia, a weaker yen destabilizes regional FX markets, pushing Korea, Taiwan, and ASEAN central banks into defensive postures and adding fuel to the fragmentation of global liquidity.

The yen carry trade is another fault line. For decades, cheap Japanese funding lubricated global risk taking, from emerging market debt to crypto. A sustained rise in JGB yields threatens that structure. If the BOJ is forced to let the yen strengthen in defense of financial stability, carry trades unwind, volatility spikes, and liquidity sensitive assets could be hit hard.

Japan‚Äôs long end reckoning is therefore more than a domestic crisis, it is a global shockwave. For the U.S., it means the Fed may cut rates but still find mortgages and long bonds stubbornly elevated. For Europe, it means a harsher test of fiscal credibility. For emerging markets, it means yet another source of currency and funding volatility. And for global investors, it signals the end of the quiet era when Japan‚Äôs bond market acted as a stabilizer. The world‚Äôs most indebted economy is no longer providing ballast; instead, it may become the accelerant of a more unstable global rate structure.

@yuriymatso is right global M2 money supply just exploded by $5 trillion in a matter of months, rocketing from $105T to $110T. That‚Äôs historically aggressive and would, in a textbook world, suggest a flood of liquidity into markets. But a deeper look reveals that this isn‚Äôt the kind of growth markets experienced during post-COVID QE it‚Äôs not organic, coordinated stimulus. This is defensive, fragmented liquidity, born out of systemic stress.

Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs really driving the spike:
‚Ä¢China has quietly restarted credit injections via local government financing vehicles (LGFVs) and bond market interventions to contain property sector collapse.

‚Ä¢Japan‚Äôs JGB market is in chaos, forcing Japanese institutions to sell U.S. Treasuries and reallocate capital domestically an internal liquidity event with external spillover.

‚Ä¢Europe is cushioning fiscal fragility through energy subsidies and lending backstops, adding to M2 through sovereign balance sheet risk.

‚Ä¢And in the U.S., while the Fed remains tight, liquidity is seeping in through the Treasury General Account (TGA) drawdown, reverse repo runoff, and a stealth rise in federal spending.

But here‚Äôs the critical nuance: this M2 isn‚Äôt evenly distributed, nor is it fully circulating. Much of it is getting absorbed by government bond issuance or hoarded by banks bracing for credit defaults. In some regions (like China), it‚Äôs trapped in broken transmission systems where banks are flush but unwilling to lend. In others (like Japan), it‚Äôs recycling through pension and insurer channels as they scramble to rebalance risk.

2.If this liquidity proves inert, and velocity stays flat, asset price inflation could hit a wall by summer triggering another rotation out of cyclicals.

4.  Watch for FX pressure. If the DXY continues falling despite yield advantages, it confirms capital is flowing toward where liquidity is usable not just available.

In short: liquidity is back but it‚Äôs nervous, asymmetric, and potentially trapped. Markets know it‚Äôs there, but they haven‚Äôt priced in how little of it may actually reach the real economy. Follow @yuriymatso  üí™

If current trends continue, we are likely 12 to 18 months away from the full onset of the largest global easing cycle in modern financial history and we may already be in the early stages of it. The seeds are being sown by a toxic convergence: weakening global demand, rising sovereign debt servicing costs, trade war escalation, and rapidly deteriorating Treasury auctions (evidenced by tail size and poor bid-to-covers). Central banks, particularly the Fed, are boxed in by structurally high deficits and a politically untenable cost of capital. As growth slows under the weight of tariffs and tighter credit, and inflation begins to cool, the pivot window opens fast.

What‚Äôs different this time is the magnitude and coordination of what will be required. The U.S. is headed toward quasi-fiscal dominance, with interest payments exceeding defense spending, and foreign buyers retreating from U.S. Treasuries. Europe is seeing fiscal expansion amid slowing exports, and Japan is quietly managing yield curve control. Emerging markets already strained will be forced to follow suit or devalue. We are likely to see synchronized rate cuts, fiscal stimulus, and balance sheet expansion across major economies, not out of choice, but as an act of global financial survival. The softening in oil prices, collapsing sentiment, and instability in rate markets are flashing early warning signs of this break.

The most revealing signal isn‚Äôt CPI it‚Äôs liquidity mechanics: worsening bond market internals, widening tails in auctions, the divergence between equity rallies and bond stress, and a creeping bid for gold as a base asset. Central banks are watching these fragilities very closely. Once volatility forces a credit event or the labor market decisively cracks, intervention will be immediate, overwhelming, and historic in scale. This will be a ‚Äòwhatever it takes‚Äô moment, not to stimulate growth, but to prevent a cascade.

If correct, we‚Äôll look back on 2025‚Äì2026 as the beginning of the Post-Volcker Era: where central banks drop the pretense of independence, and easing becomes permanent policy cover for a fundamentally insolvent sovereign framework. Rates may not go deeply negative in nominal terms in the U.S., but real rates will be engineered deeply negative for years, possibly a decade, in a strategy of stealth default. The next easing cycle won‚Äôt be a pause between hikes it will mark the formal end of sound money in the developed world.

Treasury Buybacks Begin: Not QE But the Signal Is Loud and Clear

The U.S. Treasury held its first official debt buyback in decades. The numbers speak volumes: $30.022 billion in bonds were offered by the market. The Treasury only accepted $4 billion.

On paper, it was a modest operation targeting off-the-run notes maturing between mid-2025 and mid-2027. But in reality, this was a neon warning flashing from deep within the U.S. sovereign debt system.

Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs actually going on and why it matters.

‚Äî

1. A Liquidity Squeeze in Disguise

That $30B in sell-side interest wasn‚Äôt just traders looking for clean-up bids. It was a market-wide scramble to offload short-dated Treasuries that no longer clear cleanly in secondary markets.

This isn‚Äôt typical behavior for bonds maturing in under two years. It suggests:
‚Ä¢Dealers are saturated and can‚Äôt warehouse more duration, even on the short end.
‚Ä¢Foreign holders may be raising cash, possibly rotating into gold, FX, or liquidity.
‚Ä¢Money managers want to de-risk before volatility returns.

The message: the bid for Treasuries is there but only if someone steps in to take the other side.

‚Äî

2. Why Treasury Only Took $4B

They‚Äôre threading the needle. Accepting the full $30B would‚Äôve screamed ‚ÄúQE by another name‚Äù and risked political and market fallout. But doing nothing would‚Äôve exposed liquidity fractures.

So they settled on a symbolic $4B just enough to stabilize but small enough to deny accusations of monetization.

This is the U.S. Treasury functioning as a market backstop, not just an issuer. It‚Äôs a pivot in role and posture.

‚Äî

3. This Is Functionally Shadow QE

Let‚Äôs be honest. The Federal Reserve hasn‚Äôt formally resumed quantitative easing but the Treasury just engaged in balance sheet management with QE-style impact:
‚Ä¢It removed supply.
‚Ä¢It helped dealer books.
‚Ä¢It eased rollover risk in the belly of the curve.

We‚Äôve seen versions of this before:
‚Ä¢2019 repo bailouts disguised as ‚Äútemporary liquidity.‚Äù
‚Ä¢The Bank of England‚Äôs Gilt rescue in 2022.
‚Ä¢The Fed‚Äôs 1967‚Äì68 bond support behind the curtain.

This is a modern version of financial repression dressed up as market hygiene.

‚Äî

4. Why This Moment Matters

With 95% of issuance now stacked on the short end of the curve, the U.S. Treasury is more exposed than ever to rollover risk, duration mismatches, and confidence slippage.

These buybacks aren‚Äôt just technical operations. They are:
‚Ä¢Damage control for dealer balance sheets
‚Ä¢Liquidity insurance as debt issuance soars
‚Ä¢A signal that traditional demand channels are buckling

This move doesn‚Äôt solve the problem it buys time.

‚Äî

The Real Takeaway

This wasn‚Äôt QE but it rhymed.

A $30B supply of bonds begging for a bid, met with only $4B accepted, shows how deep the stress runs even in short-duration Treasuries. That‚Äôs not normal. That‚Äôs a warning.

If buybacks expand, it will evolve into stealth QE. If they stop, we risk dislocations in credit, equities, and dollar funding markets.

And if foreign holders read this as soft monetization? Expect pressure in gold, commodities, and FX.

We‚Äôre not in a QE regime yet. But the Treasury just told us how close we are.

‚∏ª

8. The EndGame Take

This is not the end of the bond selloff. This is the beginning of a systemic protest.
It‚Äôs not just about inflation. It‚Äôs about credibility. The Fed is cornered. The Treasury is overextended. And the global market just called the bluff.

tweets.text:
This Isn‚Äôt About a Housing Shortage..It‚Äôs About Herding Americans Into the Cities

When Powell says there‚Äôs a long term housing shortage, he‚Äôs not telling the full story. It‚Äôs not that we haven‚Äôt built enough homes overall, it‚Äôs that the government, at all levels, is subtly pushing people to live where they want them to live: denser, more centralized, easier to govern urban cores. The housing shortage narrative is less about physical scarcity and more about shaping future population distribution.

Here‚Äôs what they‚Äôre not saying out loud.

Boomers currently own about 40% of U.S. housing. Over the next 15‚Äì20 years, that entire generation will gradually disappear. By the 2040s, a massive wave of inheritance, downsizing, and death will flood the market with homes, many of which are in suburban or rural areas. If we had a population to replace them, maybe it‚Äôd balance out. But we don‚Äôt. The U.S. fertility rate is hovering at 1.62 far below replacement. That means even with immigration, population growth is stagnating, and in many places outright declining.

So why claim we haven‚Äôt built enough? Because the homes that are emptying out aren‚Äôt in the right places. The system wants people where they‚Äôre easier to serve, surveil, and tax inside or around major economic hubs.

Japan already lived through this. Once their population started declining, the government quietly stopped funding smaller towns. Schools closed. Local transit systems were abandoned. Hospitals couldn‚Äôt keep staff. Public investment concentrated around Tokyo, Osaka, and a few regional centers. Over a few decades, millions were effectively forced to migrate inward, not by direct order, but by making rural life too fragile to sustain. Entire communities became hollowed out. You don‚Äôt need barbed wire when you can just shut off the budget.

Now we‚Äôre watching the U.S. start to take the same path. Think about the places where housing is unaffordable. It‚Äôs not Akron, Ohio or Little Rock, Arkansas. It‚Äôs New York, Boston, Austin, San Diego, Miami, tech and finance corridors, government adjacent hubs, and strategic coastal metros. These are the places where the next generation of productive Americans are expected to live. And these are the only places where this supposed ‚Äúhousing shortage‚Äù exists.

The real game is to label the issue a national shortage, funnel incentives toward urban development, keep zoning tight in prime markets to drive scarcity, and use high rates to freeze mobility and trap renters. Meanwhile, quietly allow legacy housing in depopulating areas to decay or fall into the hands of investors, REITs, or government programs that will control who lives there next.

This isn‚Äôt conspiracy, it‚Äôs urban planning disguised as economic concern.

They don‚Äôt want more housing everywhere. They want more people in fewer places. Easier to monitor, more efficient to manage, and politically more compliant. That‚Äôs the future this narrative is laying the groundwork for, not a shortage, but a restructuring.

What the Fed Isn‚Äôt Saying But Is Quietly Preparing For

The Federal Reserve isn‚Äôt sounding alarms. It‚Äôs publishing clinical, seemingly routine documents that, when read together, quietly sketch the blueprint of a monetary regime that‚Äôs running out of road. Two recent releases, The 2025 Stress Test Results and The Zero Lower Bound Remains a Medium-Term Risk, don‚Äôt just reflect a worst case scenario. They encode the Fed‚Äôs base case expectation: that the next economic downturn will be so severe, so fast moving, and so volatile that rates won‚Äôt just fall, they‚Äôll slam into zero again and stay there.

The stress test simulates a collapse: a 50% stock market plunge, 30% commercial real estate drawdown, 7.8% GDP contraction, 10% unemployment, and an immediate drop in short-term interest rates to zero. That‚Äôs not a stress test, it‚Äôs a controlled demolition scenario. The banks are shown to survive only because the model assumes continued profitability based on trailing earnings. In reality, pre-provision net revenue vanishes quickly in crises. So while the capital buffers look solid on paper, they depend on lagging metrics and heroic assumptions. If earnings evaporate, as they almost always do during shocks, the entire capital position deteriorates just as losses mount. This isn‚Äôt resilience. It‚Äôs a fragile placeholder.

Now layer in the Fed‚Äôs parallel analysis from Liberty Street Economics. Despite rates hovering above 5%, the probability of hitting the zero lower bound again within seven years is already 9%. But that figure is conservative. The real driver isn‚Äôt the current level of rates, it‚Äôs the level of macro uncertainty. The Fed‚Äôs own distributional modeling shows that when volatility rises, even without recession, policy space collapses. The path dependency of market expectations pulls the entire yield curve toward the floor. In short: the more unstable the outlook, the faster the Fed loses room to maneuver.

Read together, these reports offer a candid glimpse into what the Fed sees coming, but cannot say out loud. They are preparing for a regime where interest rates become ineffective, where liquidity, not price, is the only lever left. And they know it will not be a soft landing. The implication is that the system is already overstretched, and the next true shock will corner the Fed back into 2008‚Äì2020 playbooks of emergency lending, QE, collateral backstops, FX swaps, and a return to the floor of the zero bound.

This isn‚Äôt overreaction or academic hedging. It‚Äôs quiet forewarning. A document trail that positions the Fed to claim foresight when the next crisis erupts. Not because they can stop it, but because they expect to be powerless when it arrives. If you read carefully, the message is unmistakable.

They‚Äôre not just modeling collapse. They‚Äôre bracing for it. And they know the economy will break hard enough to drag rates back to zero‚Ä¶again.

The Brazilian real (BRL) would likely sell off aggressively, triggering a spike in domestic inflation, particularly in food and energy. The Central Bank of Brazil would be forced into a corner: either raise rates to defend the currency and suffocate domestic credit, or let the BRL collapse further and risk a full blown inflationary spiral. Meanwhile, capital outflows from Brazilian equities and bonds would accelerate, particularly from dollar aligned pension funds and institutional managers unwilling to hold exposure to a country veering toward systemic geopolitical divergence.

China would respond quickly by moving to insulate Brazil via long dated commodity pre-purchase agreements and bilateral swap lines in yuan, trying to lock in strategic access to soy, beef, and iron ore while shielding Brazil from U.S. dollar volatility. But the deeper Brazil leans on China for monetary lifelines, the more it exposes itself to financial monoculture, a dependence that lacks global depth, FX liquidity, and reserve scale trust. That‚Äôs where the U.S. can strike.

To truly drive the stake in, the U.S. must wield the dollar not just as a reserve asset, but as a strategic weaponized ecosystem. That means two things: first, the U.S. Treasury and Fed can pull dollar liquidity from Brazil‚Äôs short term funding channels, by quietly pressuring U.S. banks and dollar clearing networks to reduce exposure or tighten swap lines. This would push up local funding costs, restrict access to trade finance, and make BRL-dollar conversion increasingly expensive. Even if not formally sanctioned, this ‚Äúshadow embargo‚Äù on dollar liquidity would strangle Brazilian importers and corporates reliant on dollar based invoicing.

Second, the U.S. can dangle selective reintegration into the dollar based system as a conditional reward. Offer Brazil special access to T-bill auctions, targeted infrastructure financing through OPIC or the IDB, or even invite them into a limited Western-aligned commodity security pact but only if they scale back yuan denominated settlement initiatives and recommit to U.S. centric trade architecture. In this way, the dollar isn‚Äôt just a currency, it becomes a gatekeeper to liquidity, investment, and systemic inclusion.

This is how you don‚Äôt just punish a BRICS defector, you collapse its monetary hedging game and force strategic submission through the very thing it tried to escape: the gravity of the U.S. dollar.

What‚Äôs happening in the Treasury market is a signal that the foundation of demand, especially at the long end of the curve, is weakening. Over the past week, both the 10-year and 30-year auctions tailed, meaning the government had to offer higher than expected yields to attract enough buyers. A tail of one or two basis points might seem minor, but in a market as deep as Treasuries, it matters. It reflects discomfort. The buyers are still there but they‚Äôre hesitant, and they‚Äôre starting to ask for more to take on duration risk.

The bigger issue is who‚Äôs buying and who‚Äôs not. Foreign central banks, long the reliable backbone of Treasury demand, have been stepping back. Institutional investors are cautious. That leaves primary dealers and domestic banks to pick up the slack. But these aren‚Äôt natural buyers. They‚Äôre intermediaries who are being forced to absorb more and more supply just to keep the auctions from failing outright out of necessity. And that‚Äôs a problem, because it creates a fragile foundation. Dealers don‚Äôt want to hold long duration Treasuries. They want to offload them. But if no one‚Äôs there to take the other side, the risk shifts back to the system.

Contrast that with the front end of the curve, where demand remains strong. Treasury bills are flying off the shelves. On the surface, that looks like confidence in U.S. debt, but the reality is more technical. Bills aren‚Äôt just safe, they‚Äôre useful. They‚Äôre the best collateral in the system, and collateral demand is sky high. Banks, funds, and counterparties need bills to grease the wheels of repo, FX swaps, and derivative markets. That need for pristine collateral creates persistent demand at the short end that has nothing to do with confidence in long term U.S. fiscal policy.

Adding to that is the rise of stablecoin issuers as major buyers of T-bills. As of July 2025, the top four stablecoin issuers are Tether, Circle, Paxos, and First Digital who collectively hold over $180 billion in Treasury securities, with Tether alone accounting for more than $125 billion. These firms are required to back their digital dollar tokens with ultra safe, ultra liquid assets, typically T-bills maturing in 90 days or less. Their demand is large, but it‚Äôs concentrated, regulatory driven, and highly reactive to crypto market dynamics. If flows reverse or regulations change, that demand could vanish quickly.

So while the front end looks strong, it‚Äôs not the kind of strength that supports the broader Treasury complex. It‚Äôs narrow and functional. The long end is where the real stress is building. That‚Äôs where auctions are tailing, foreign demand is slipping, and dealers are being forced to absorb more. And with over $1.5 trillion in net issuance coming in the second half of 2025, this imbalance is only going to get worse.

Looking ahead, the highest conviction outcome is a continued breakdown in long end market confidence. If the Fed cuts rates, it could spark fears of inflation and fiscal monetization, driving long yields even higher. If the Fed holds, the pressure on domestic banks and dealers will mount. Either way, something eventually breaks. The real risk is that weak auctions become routine. That the market starts treating Treasuries not as the world‚Äôs safest asset but just another risk needing a premium. And once that shift in perception takes hold, there‚Äôs no easy way back.

üáØüáµ Japan‚Äôs 40-Year Bond Yield Spikes

Japan‚Äôs 40-year government bond yield just surged to 3.39%, its highest level in over two decades. On the surface, this might look like a local bond market event but in reality, it‚Äôs a flashing warning signal for the entire global financial system. Let‚Äôs break down why this matters, what it really signals beneath the surface, and how it could trigger a cascade of cross-market volatility.

1. Why This Matters: The Cracks in Japan‚Äôs Financial Repression Model

For decades, Japan has relied on financial repression keeping interest rates artificially low to manage its staggering 260% debt-to-GDP ratio. The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has been the perpetual buyer of last resort, owning nearly half of all Japanese Government Bonds (JGBs). But this latest yield surge tells us the long end of the curve is breaking free from BOJ control.
‚Ä¢Pensions and Insurance Stress: Japanese pension funds and life insurers, which are heavily invested in ultra-long bonds, now face severe mark-to-market losses.
‚Ä¢BOJ‚Äôs Yield Curve Control (YCC) Is Functionally Dead: While the BOJ still officially targets the 10-year yield, the market is now forcing its hand on the long end.
‚Ä¢Repatriation Risk: Japanese institutional investors may begin pulling capital back home to take advantage of these higher domestic yields. That means selling U.S. Treasuries and European bonds, potentially pushing global yields higher.

2. Is This a Strategic Play by the BOJ?

Governor Ueda may be signaling a policy shift without formally announcing it. Instead of directly intervening in FX markets to defend the yen, Japan might be allowing long-term yields to rise as a way to strengthen the currency by making domestic bonds more attractive.
‚Ä¢Yen Defense via Rate Differentials: Higher Japanese yields narrow the interest rate gap with the U.S., which helps support the yen and discourages speculative short positions in the currency.
‚Ä¢Avoiding FX Reserve Drawdowns: By defending the yen through bond yields rather than selling U.S. dollar reserves, Japan preserves its financial firepower for a more serious crisis.

3. Global Ramifications: This Is Not Contained to Japan
‚Ä¢U.S. Treasury Market Impact: Japan remains the largest foreign holder of U.S. Treasuries. If Japanese funds accelerate selling to capture higher domestic yields, it could push U.S. long-term yields even higher, creating a feedback loop of tightening financial conditions.
‚Ä¢Global Credit Contraction: Rising global yields tighten financial conditions across the board, putting further stress on over-leveraged corporate balance sheets and fragile sovereign debt markets, especially in emerging markets.
‚Ä¢Volatility Surge Ahead: Expect bond volatility (tracked by the MOVE Index) to spike, and equity markets to face increased pressure as risk-free rates climb and equity risk premiums are recalculated.

Historical Parallel: The 1998 Japan-LTCM Crisis Echo

This situation echoes the 1998 Japanese bond market crisis, when a sharp rise in Japanese yields triggered massive losses for global funds like LTCM that were heavily leveraged into carry trades. The difference now? The scale is far larger, and Japan‚Äôs economy is even more intertwined with global capital markets.

High-Conviction Takeaway: A Strategic Inflection Point

This is not an accident. It‚Äôs a calculated shift by the BOJ to regain some control over its financial system and currency before a larger global credit event unfolds. The options from here are binary:
1.BOJ Capitulates: If Japan‚Äôs economy weakens rapidly and equities collapse, the BOJ may have no choice but to resume aggressive bond purchases, crashing the yen and reigniting global carry trades.
2.BOJ Holds the Line: If the BOJ is serious about defending the yen and domestic financial stability, this higher yield regime could become permanent risking a deflationary shock but restoring some balance sheet integrity.

The End of the Long Game: Where We Stand in the 5,000-Year Interest Rate Cycle and What Comes Next

If you want to understand the forces that have shaped civilization‚Äôs economic foundations for 5,000 years, there may be no better visual than the chart from Edward Chancellor‚Äôs @chancellor_e brilliant work, The Price of Time: The Real Story of Interest.

This is more than a historical chart it‚Äôs a roadmap of human behavior, trust in institutions, the value of capital, and ultimately, the price of time itself. And as you can see, we‚Äôre standing at the very edge of that historical precipice.

‚∏ª

Where Are We Now? The Terminal Phase of the Interest Rate Supercycle

We are deep into the final chapter of the lowest interest rate environment in recorded history a period known as the Zero Bound Trap. Unlike previous cycles, this one isn‚Äôt regional or isolated it‚Äôs global, systemic, and policy-engineered.
‚Ä¢Central Banks Are Cornered:
For over a decade, they pursued a singular belief: cheap money equals growth. But instead of fostering productive investment, it inflated asset bubbles, encouraged reckless speculation, and misallocated trillions into unproductive ventures.
‚Ä¢Global Debt Has Reached Historic Extremes:
Total debt now exceeds $300 trillion, a level that requires interest rates to stay suppressed indefinitely or risk triggering a widespread sovereign and corporate default crisis.
‚Ä¢Demographic Collapse Meets Productivity Stagnation:
The developed world is aging rapidly, while productivity growth stagnates. This is a dangerous echo of the 1930s Depression Era, where deflationary forces and debt overhang collided with a generational demand shortfall.
‚Ä¢Markets Are Addicted to Easy Money:
We‚Äôve reached a psychological breaking point where even modest rate hikes trigger violent market corrections. The financial system has been structurally rebuilt on the assumption that money will remain cheap forever.

‚∏ª

What Comes Next? The Three Possible Endgames

1. The Controlled Reset ‚Äì Financial Repression 2.0
‚Ä¢Central banks attempt to engineer a slow-motion deleveraging by keeping rates low and letting inflation run above target.
‚Ä¢Savers are silently taxed through negative real returns, while governments inflate away debt burdens.
‚Ä¢Historical Parallel: Post-World War II debt liquidation via financial repression.
‚Ä¢Likely Outcome: Stagnant growth, rising inequality, social unrest, and gradual fiat currency debasement but no immediate system collapse.

2. The Disorderly Debt Jubilee ‚Äì Default or Hyperinflation
‚Ä¢If trust in currency systems breaks, the path shifts rapidly to default or hyperinflation as debt becomes unserviceable.
‚Ä¢Historical Parallel: Weimar Germany in the 1920s, or Latin America in the 1980s.
‚Ä¢Likely Outcome: A middle-class wipeout, collapse of pension systems, political extremism, and a flight to hard assets like gold, commodities, and land.

3. The New Monetary Order ‚Äì Bretton Woods III
‚Ä¢Recognizing the endgame, policymakers coordinate a new global financial architecture perhaps built around CBDCs, a commodity-backed currency basket, or a multipolar reserve system led by BRICS+.
‚Ä¢Historical Parallel: The 1944 Bretton Woods Agreement or Nixon‚Äôs 1971 shock ending gold convertibility.
‚Ä¢Likely Outcome: High volatility during the transition, but eventual stabilization under a new monetary framework designed to restore trust and control inflation.

‚∏ª

The Greatest Risk Is Believing Nothing Will Change

History is clear: long periods of financial repression and low interest rates always end often violently.
‚Ä¢If central banks tighten too aggressively into a fragile system, we face a deflationary debt collapse.
‚Ä¢If they refuse to tighten and inflation spirals, the system burns itself down through currency debasement.

The question isn‚Äôt if the regime ends it‚Äôs how it ends and whether you‚Äôre prepared for it.

When the Fed cuts into a disinflationary or risk off backdrop, capital floods into the deepest collateral pools and that still means U.S. dollars and Treasuries. The rate cut becomes the trigger for a flight to dollar safety, not a flight from it.

That‚Äôs where the geopolitical trap springs shut. Powell‚Äôs refusal to cut thus far, despite softening labor markets and collapsing consumer sentiment may not be driven solely by domestic macro data. It could be a strategic delay, engineered to lure BRICS and non-aligned nations deeper into dedollarization efforts just as liquidity begins to fracture. These countries have repositioned in local currencies, gold, and bilateral trade pacts. But they‚Äôve also left themselves highly exposed to a dollar squeeze, especially if USD liabilities remain in their corporate or sovereign debt structures. Once the Fed cuts, the ensuing surge in dollar demand (for collateral, safety, and relative yield) could catch them completely offsides, forcing them to scramble back into the very system they tried to exit.

This wouldn‚Äôt be the first time such a trap has been sprung. The dollar surged after 2019‚Äôs Fed cuts. It exploded higher during the March 2020 crisis. And in the 1997‚Äì98 Asian Financial Crisis, nations that tried to assert monetary independence were crushed by sudden dollar strength. History shows us that when global actors overestimate their insulation from dollar liquidity cycles, they suffer. Powell holding the line on rate cuts may be less about the domestic economy and more about setting the stage for a strategic snapback, one that reasserts dollar dominance precisely when the rest of the world thinks it‚Äôs fading.

‚∏ª

Buffett is quietly flagging one of the most serious risks he‚Äôs ever hinted at: a loss of confidence in U.S. monetary or political stability. Unlike past market drawdowns or economic downturns, this isn‚Äôt about inflation or recession this is about the integrity of the U.S. as a financial anchor.

What Buffett Could Be Signaling:
1.A Sovereign-Grade Dollar Risk
He may believe that U.S. policy decisions whether fiscal, monetary, or political are now posing structural threats to the dollar‚Äôs trustworthiness. That could include:
‚Ä¢A looming Treasury market crisis or loss of foreign confidence in U.S. debt
‚Ä¢Weaponized monetary policy leading to stealth devaluation
‚Ä¢Political instability or regulatory dysfunction creating capital controls risk
2.Regime Fragility, Not Just Inflation
This isn‚Äôt a repeat of 1970s-style inflation hedging. Buffett isn‚Äôt recommending gold. He‚Äôs implying that owning dollars themselves may no longer be safe in all scenarios. That‚Äôs a fundamental shift. It‚Äôs the kind of concern that normally triggers sovereign portfolio rebalancing not just corporate hedging.
3.Strategic Positioning for Multipolar Finance
With BRICS countries accelerating de-dollarization and U.S. trade tensions heating up, Buffett may be preparing for a world where global reserves and trade invoicing fragment. In that scenario, exposure to other currencies isn‚Äôt opportunistic it‚Äôs essential to preserve purchasing power and operational sovereignty.

Why This Moment Stands Apart:

Buffett has never said anything like this in previous crises:
‚Ä¢In 2008, he bought U.S. equities and reaffirmed dollar strength.
‚Ä¢In 2020, during COVID, he was cautious but never questioned the dollar.
‚Ä¢Even in the dot-com collapse, he focused on valuation excess, not currency integrity.

Now in 2025 with U.S. GDP contracting, Treasury yields spiking, Taiwan‚Äôs FX market snapping violently, and Berkshire still hoarding cash Buffett suddenly invokes currency flight risk? That‚Äôs not coincidence. That‚Äôs coordination.

‚∏ª

Implications:

This is not just a market commentary. This is a warning from America‚Äôs most trusted capital allocator that the dollar may no longer be unquestionable. It suggests Berkshire is preparing for:
‚Ä¢A multi-currency balance sheet
‚Ä¢A global realignment of trust in sovereign finance
‚Ä¢And potentially, a period of instability where the U.S. itself becomes a source of global financial risk

‚∏ª

Conclusion:

Buffett didn‚Äôt say this by accident. His firm is hitting all-time highs. He has more cash than ever. And yet instead of celebrating the strength of the U.S. system, he‚Äôs floating the idea of owning foreign currencies to protect against American risk.

‚∏ª

Strategic Context:

The Strait of Hormuz is the most critical maritime chokepoint in the world. Roughly 20% of globally traded crude oil and 30% of global LNG shipments transit its narrow waters daily. If Iran were to close or significantly disrupt the Strait via mining, anti ship missiles, drone swarms, or fast-attack naval craft it would initiate not just a regional crisis, but a systemic shock to the global economy, supply chains, and security architecture.

‚∏ª

First-Order Effects (Immediate ‚Äì Week 1)

Energy Spike: Crude oil could surge $30‚Äì$60 in days. Brent could reach $130‚Äì$150 depending on the perceived duration of disruption. Natural gas, especially LNG bound for Asia, would become acutely scarce. Expect JKM LNG benchmarks in Japan and Korea to spike.

Markets Rattle: U.S. Treasuries initially bid on safety, but duration risk quickly re-emerges as inflation expectations surge. Equities fall across the board, led by energy-sensitive sectors. VIX jumps above 25‚Äì30, with MOVE rising in tandem. The dollar may rally on safe-haven flows short term, but this masks structural fractures beneath the surface.

Naval and Kinetic Escalation: The U.S. Fifth Fleet, based in Bahrain, would mobilize rapidly. Mine clearing, naval escorts, and possibly kinetic strikes against Iranian coastal positions would follow. Israel may act preemptively in Lebanon or Syria, fearing regional encirclement.

‚∏ª

Second-Order Effects (Week 2‚Äì4)

Global Trade Shocks: Energy shipping is rerouted around the Cape of Good Hope, increasing cost and delivery time. Marine insurance premiums soar. Container shipping prices spike again, particularly to Europe and Asia. Expect secondary port congestion and cascading logistical delays.

Macro Repricing: Central banks in energy-importing countries (India, Japan, EU) begin defensive FX interventions and emergency energy procurement. Expect drawdowns in reserves, sovereign wealth reallocation, and possible covert bilateral deals with Gulf producers.

Supply Chain Strain: Fertilizer prices climb due to natural gas shortages. Food commodities spike especially wheat and soybeans. Nations reliant on subsidized energy (Pakistan, Egypt, Indonesia) face currency stress and domestic instability.

(1/2) Liquidity Support Is No Longer a Crisis Response. It‚Äôs the New Operating System.

A recent chart from the Federal Reserve‚Äôs FRED database reveals something markets have yet to fully digest: the era of emergency liquidity is no longer defined by crisis. It has become a permanent feature of the financial system.

The image compares various Fed credit facilities used during major stress periods: 2008, 2020, and now 2023‚Äì2025. What was once a tool of last resort has become a standing architecture holding the financial system together.

Let‚Äôs break down what it really shows.

What the Chart Tells Us

In 2008, the spike in liquidity support came as the banking system broke. Programs like Primary Credit and Term Auction Facilities were deployed to contain a localized credit crisis. The stress was internal to the financial system. The solution was temporary, and the system slowly reset.

In 2020, the pandemic shock drove an even more aggressive wave of programs: the PPP Liquidity Facility, expanded repo operations, and direct asset purchases. But here too, it was justified as a temporary bridge across a health and labor market collapse.

Now, the 2023‚Äì2025 spike tells a different story. The size and persistence of programs like the Bank Term Funding Program (BTFP) suggest that the system is no longer correcting it is adapting to fragility.

This is not a return to normal. This is a transition to a new regime.

We Are in a Structural Liquidity Trap

Unlike 2008, the core fragility is no longer in subprime mortgages or bank balance sheets. It is in the sovereign debt structure itself. The U.S. must roll over trillions in short dated debt at much higher interest rates. That rollover risk is being masked by collateral transformation facilities, par-value lending, and implied yield curve control through duration backstopping.

The Fed is not fighting inflation anymore. It is fighting duration collapse while pretending it still has monetary independence.

This Is Not QE by Name, But QE by Function

The BTFP and related programs are not labeled quantitative easing. But they achieve the same outcome. The Fed is absorbing collateral at above-market prices, injecting liquidity, and suppressing volatility. This is shadow QE, and it‚Äôs now essential to Treasury market function.

Banks, meanwhile, have adapted. They are no longer pricing risk. They are warehousing duration, pledging it to the Fed, and recycling that capital back into short-term funding markets. This is how moral hazard becomes institutionalized.
